jurisdiction.title: Holy Spirit Catholic School Division - Alberta, Canada

A17562CF1C7A4DC9BB65CBAE0780B0DE.description: Participate in a variety of dances from New France

53C6EB13FAA34E53A2E59EDCE4CE7D32.description: Observe a variety of cultural dances as an inspiration for talking about dance.

F57A8C831F9C424FB6E7F964C975FECC.description: Explore pantomime as a dance form

E86C12CC94CC4D3291ADA495BD3A854B.description: Create movement and dance within formations and pathways common to dance in ancient Rome

B453821DA2D448E59C34A1A98E9E158E.description: Demonstrate artistic protocols and etiquette in various dance experiences.

3814A0D218AD4A1BAFDCF32A51B45F42.description: Use dance vocabulary when responding to and discussing dance performances.

64B560704150474A9435F725D1782A2A.description: Participate in a variety of folk and social dances

DAFBC2CC932144B69C2A607C7C60E08B.description: Describe how dance can be valued in one's life and culture.

504F5A4EB33849CA9FA9A9550DFAACA0.description: Dance in New France reflected a combination of culture and traditions

03F4CAA07E9946D19B9078FE0F18D4DC.description: Dance was used as a means of entertainment, cultural adornment, or as a status symbol in ancient Rome

9C0DF9242498454A91CF6091AD0BD21A.description: Ancient Roman culture was reflected through dance traditions and beliefs

3589E28F5B2749AF91C60931D03C79B5.description: An artistic community is a venue for artistic expression within various cultures

CCA78A7439174BF6A9875AC5F9588217.description: Dance can be valued differently across cultures throughout history.

196BE21A44BB46B68945E2698D6CF183.description: People in New France valued dance for the significance, meaning, and function that it had in their lives, and it could be performed by anyone

09720F6CFDFF4348898EE2795EECA656.description: European settlers introduced many folk dances, styles, and traditions to New France, including jigging the Pavane la ronde the menuet le quadrille la danse de la Galette square dance (les contredanses en carre)

91E2A30FCF1F4A42A88184B58868ECB3.description: First Nations dances in New France reflected the traditions, ceremony, and rituals of the people who lived on the land for hundreds of years prior to European settlement

8257F81A6061405A9ED4C5D940AC93A9.description: Dance formations and pathways in ancient Rome can include choral line circular processional

9050D1986B3F493099A5141E3E402136.description: Pantomime is non-verbal style of communicating dramatic stories using gestures, music, costumes, and masks

E842840836DE47E392E13C99400E16DE.description: Pantomime was considered a popular form of dance in ancient Rome

E667014AFC5642C29BBA4544F10A272B.description: Some dances in ancient Rome had protocols that specified who could dance, when dances were performed, and who the dances were performed for

32EF77DAD7DC4DFB8DE6F32E05CF9C1D.description: Dance in ancient Rome reflected Greek culture, including celebrating Mars, the god of war, where dancers would carry a shield and wear a full set of armor while they danced

DAFAD4074FF64495A1C0E9B3F22F7027.description: Wealthy people in ancient Rome did not dance, but instead hired lower-class people to dance for them

6F55F50A310E42AF8C75317DED79134A.description: Artistic protocols and etiquette may change based on the community, culture, presentation, and location of a dance performance.

4E48F975873B445494B3FA3F68DC26ED.description: Using vocabulary related to dance can contribute to and guide discussions about dance.

A580CD985FDF4073B619EB3BB18CAB78.description: Folk dance and social dance can function as a means of participation, entertainment, and cultural expression

7FDEE6FDE62B46B981CBC6F982529447.description: Folk dance is a dance form that reflects the lives, traditions, or customs of a group of people from a specific country, region, or culture

C4B4622A9361421D8784ECBF2F73D2AC.description: From historical times to today, cultures may have valued dance for ritual or cultural expression, entertainment, and learning

BC2A0894358B424D9D2709EB9624D489.description: Students compare and contrast dance cultures of the past with modern-day dance

21031730F020424C8CCCE6093F7EC1F6.description: Appreciation: Recognizing beauty, goodness, and truth in dance can be developed by understanding the complexity and richness of great works of dance, the artists who create and perform them, and the historical and cultural contexts from which they originate

75C2E1250D5C4101A0C06C5F28937074.description: Rehearse movements and dance before performing for an audience

E9702E90B55847BE898DB42A9FCAC1D3.description: Practise giving and receiving feedback with others

592469AA8B5D4418B4DB17841E730199.description: Participate as an audience member and as a performer in a variety of dance experiences

63C3027210374D6D8069286B7B5A3150.description: Experience and discuss the significance of a Round Dance

7032AF2C2BEB438A8007380F4C219FEC.description: Respond to a variety of stimuli in the creation of movement and dance.

38DD00DD0A794452865BEF44EAD9F5C8.description: Experiment with movement possibilities when the elements of dance are combined with locomotor and non-locomotor movements

884BA93C36F447C38D44F2BBDBE8DBFC.description: Create a dance phrase that can be repeated and has a clear beginning and ending.

25E842495942406B9A031C4E1661C0D7.description: Explore movements within a variety of choreographic forms

12DE2B3AA4B7463D9C6A0DC9163E0BB6.description: Evaluate the effectiveness of artistic choices in communicating a message through movement.

7C136B448A6746A093456A856E2DB18E.description: Make informed artistic choices to share a message through dance.

FDE4C1110F674278832D350FE95E8B86.description: An audience can receive and interpret a message communicated through dance.

A713A50EDD1B47AC9B9A71BA559C24B2.description: Messages can represent what a dancer means to communicate through movement

27C8648BD0A649F484E7D40C9A27F8DD.description: A message is at the centre of communication in dance

888DB0A1F08B46669CAE2A69EFAB7D2B.description: The elements of dance can be combined in an infinite number of ways to create a message through movement.

329D5C53878D4E72BB605A7C55175822.description: Dancers intentionally choose ways to effectively share a message

C145542B281540A195E91AAD06993DA6.description: Creative processes can help develop and clarify a message in dance, including reflection giving and receiving feedback refinement rehearsal

9E50450983FF490895724C6F887EDDAB.description: The Round Dance is social dance often held by First Nations communities, where participants move in a clockwise direction in a circle to the beat of a drum while holding hands.

137818EB14FE4B0B9271E289D55EA344.description: In powwow dances, the spiritual centre of the powwow is the circle where unity and equality of participants is valued everyone can see each other in the circle there is no leader and everyone follows

B267B80277A14D23945394153B662772.description: The circle is a symbol that can communicate messages in dance, including unity

BCA34333A8934176997127AE8936D00B.description: The clarity of a message communicated through movement and dance can be enhanced by moving to a steady beat planning movement patterns practising movement skills combining movements with a purpose

E6CD235AA64E432D87FF00CCB2821CA3.description: A message in dance can be created in response to a variety of stimuli

1CB323B742E64BC39975CDCC2DBC3307.description: Messages can represent a variety of things, including ideas, experiences, or feelings.

A51AC155F7E54F2AB70326EADD4878E7.description: Choreographic forms can structure how a message is conveyed in dance, including AB (binary form) ABA (ternary form)

B4B01FDCB3134F82A20B21F1DE30619E.description: Movement ideas are shared effectively when they have a clear beginning and end.

05582015CA04411D967BEAD1860C2328.description: Intentional artistic choices are made by dancers to express a message using locomotor and non-locomotor movements space, including use of proximity, levels, size, direction, and pathways body, including body parts? body shapes? balance? and relationships to other dancers, including prepositions body shapes and balance force speed

A4132D91B12C4896968794B770EF5A6C.description: Students represent message through artistic choices related to the elements of dance.

7E1FB01D6E3F4897915F15DBF8BED932.description: Creating and presenting: Ideas can be represented through movement and dance that draw upon foundational knowledge

597C8AAD9CD34F1EAA44EB7A19235E2E.description: Experience how a force can emphasize a movement

0D63D6FA3495480A9D2F0DE3701BB9A9.description: Observe a variety of dances to investigate how movement qualities can change when force is applied

62954BA6D3F04B9FA5D6949E6BBB5A6E.description: Investigate how meaning can be communicated when force is applied to locomotor and nonlocomotor movements.

445930D6F63844179AB6CE79106E8C71.description: Perform movements that reflect the qualities of energy in various pieces of music

097EEBFF9BE74258AC002DE7CF6DD865.description: Participate in warm-ups that prepare the body's muscles for executing force.

034BBFF1BFCC47A0AA08FE60B624E930.description: Identify how the quality of a movement can vary when strong or light weight is applied.

770A7E19EADF48DB8DD83F075BC2F56E.description: Discuss the importance of awareness for others when applying force, speed, and change of direction during movement along various pathways and in various formations.

941F6F4FBE254945A5A3B1F2AF584A4B.description: Differentiate between smooth and sharp energy.

0B441970D10143E8972523F9654F0102.description: Combine element of time with other elements of dance in movement exploration

FA56ECC4CD104C5C861EFCFEC7F953D8.description: Respond to various stimuli in the exploration of time in dance.

58B7755EADE84BE7A1060DE947595D20.description: Participate in dances that are performed to music or the spoken word

E8950F57A6C54937A08025964D2CCB11.description: Identify the number of beats in various movement patterns.

C9EA49A4DEC24224B489647E6CF1719B.description: Experience counting beats silently or aloud to direct movement.

515FD09C657148BDB66A7D6886112EC8.description: Demonstrate how to move to a steady beat at various speeds.

016CD9681B944F3898BB964FAA53FE9F.description: Alter movement by varying speed and responding to different rhythms

D8B5777CE3714D9788FBC48B47671EF2.description: Force can communicate meaning through movement.

B831A6D9ECB648FC8987515501C18F70.description: Force is the amount of energy the body uses and releases in dance

82EC2CF793104F098510633966E13330.description: Time can be explored in relation to other elements of dance

96020272C04346B3A938D47DF3488AC6.description: Time is an element of dance that refers to the speed and rhythm of movement

1E87AF5200DF4074A054F32B452DFF66.description: When applied to movement, force can intensify or emphasize parts of a movement, pattern, or phrase

9DADB61E25814E48A34553194E6C43EB.description: Force can communicate feelings and ideas when applied to locomotor and non-locomotor movements

43872D9181B8440AA421B6819EEC10A8.description: Music qualities can direct how a movement is performed, including accents patterns speed dynamics

4134FDF3A9A84730BC3D352F235789C8.description: Applying force to locomotor and non-locomotor movements requires a warm-up to prepare muscles body control awareness for safe movement practices

12260A7DB66E4AC9B53378E19876B82E.description: Movements executed with light weight require little muscular force

0488EB812D3540B99E9E5ACF5C426B03.description: Movements executed with strong weight require more muscular force.

AA9FF3CFA2BC4D4C933246B2BCA94E8B.description: Force has energy that can be described using qualities, including smooth or sustained energy that is continuous sharp energy that produces force through sudden movements and ends quickly, including slash, punch, jump, or kick

DB0459ECAA7C474BA1E9B3A90CF2FE72.description: Force is an element of dance that includes energy and weight

F9C52567CACE4B13882BCA1C7A8E6E8F.description: Concepts of time can be combined with other elements of dance, including space: place, size, levels, directions, pathways, and focus body: body parts? relationships? shapes, including symmetry and asymmetry? and balance force: energy, weight, and flow

43C102BC91654EFB8D72E4C850187C76.description: Counting aloud or internalizing the number of beats in a movement pattern or dance can help a dancer know when to start and stop a movement

46D2C15733804A898DCEFBE40E1E2094.description: Time can be explored in relation to various stimuli, including music, instruments, or the spoken word

61B0C433E2DD40F2BC24A9DFFC0813D9.description: Movement patterns can include quick or slow steps performed in a sequence, which are often repetitive

FE6671B17A374C1B9E2EA401A8A5EAAC.description: Rhythm includes the pulse or constant, even beat also known as the underlying beat

3E0F71652C264899B50DD2CDD40E3B6E.description: Speed refers to how fast or slow the body moves through space

EC646779B0CB481681346FD8365B5830.description: Time is measured by how many beats a movement or stillness lasts in dance

BDFAD2573D964B6DB913E93D0E62EE74.description: Students evaluate time and force as it relates to quality of movement.

ECC3ED8084864B5AB9F722AA602237C1.description: Foundational Elements and Principles: Dance literacy is developed through knowledge and application of foundational elements and principles
